description.narrative: The development objective of the Assam Citizen-Centric Service Delivery Project for India is to improve access in the delivery of selected public services in Assam. The project comprises of two components. The first component, technical assistance will provide specialized technical assistance to support implementation of the government program and the achievement of the project development objective (PDO). It consists of following sub-components: (i) strengthening right to public services (RTPS) implementation; (ii) supporting process re-engineering in selected services; (iii) setting up public facilitation centers; and (iv) promoting citizen engagement. The second component, results-based financing aims to support the Government of Assam to implement critical public management reforms related to delivery of public services.

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Completion Report | Description :Assam to provide to the Borrower for incorporation in the report referred to inSection 5.08 (c) of the General Conditions all such information as the Borrower or the Bank shall reasonably request. | Due Date:30-Nov-2022

Finance Agreement :DLI Verification (1/2) | Description :Assam to undertake a verification process in accordance with the DLIVerification Protocol and in a manner satisfactory to the Borrower and the Bank, through the independent third party entity orentities to ascertain whether the DLI Targets have been achieved for the respective DLI Period(s) under review. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :DLI Verification (2/2) | Description :Assam to furnish to the Borrower and the Bank corresponding verificationreports, in form and substance acceptable to the Bank. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Financial Management (1/3) | Description :Borrower and Assam to have their Financial Statements audited inaccordance with the provisions of Section 5.09 (b) of the General Conditions. Each audit of the Financial Statements shall coverthe period of one fiscal year of the Borrower, commencing with the fiscal year in which the first withdrawal was made under thePreparation Advance for the Project. | Frequency :CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement :Financial Management (2/3) | Description :The audited Financial Statements for each such period shall befurnished to the Bank. in respect of Part 1 of the Project | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Financial Management (3/3) | Description :The audited Financial Statements for each such period shall befurnished to the Bank in respect of Part 2 of the Project. | Frequency :Yearly
Finance Agreement :Financial Management Manual | Description :Assam to implement the Project in accordance with the FinancialManagement Manual. | Frequency :CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement :Operations Manual | Description :Assam to adopt the Operations Manual in a form and substance satisfactory tothe Bank and implement the Project in accordance with the Operations Manual. | Due Date :18-Aug-2017

Finance Agreement :Project Guidance Council and Governing Body | Description :Assam to maintain, within ARIAS: (a) the ProjectGuidance Council, with mandate and composition satisfactory to the Bank, and responsible for the overall management of the Project;and (b) the Governing Body, with mandate and composition satisfactory to the Bank. | Frequency :CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement :Project Management Unit | Description :Assam to maintain, throughout the period of implementation of theProject, the Project Management Unit within ARIAS Society, headed by a Project director, with functions and resources satisfactoryto the Bank and with staff in adequate numbers and with qualifications, experience and terms of reference satisfactory to the Bank.| Frequency :CONTINUOUS

Finance Agreement :Safeguards | Description :Borrower and Assam to: (a) carry out the Project in accordance with the EnvironmentalManagement Plan and the Tribal Development Plan in a manner and substance satisfactory to the Bank; and (b) refrain from taking anyaction, or consenting to an action to be taken, which would prevent or interfere with the implementation of the EnvironmentalManagement Plans and/or the Tribal Development Plan. | Frequency :CONTINUOUS

title.narrative: RTPS services applications responded to within the legal time-frame.

actual.value: A study of 7 RTPS services through existing mechanisms covering 304479 applications from March 2017 to June 2019 showed 59 percentof applications were disposed within the legal timeframe.

title.narrative: Access to RTPS Services expanded to Targeted districts

actual.value: The three Autonomous Councils, Bodoland Territorial Council, Karbi Anglong Autonomous Council (KAAC) and N C Hills AutonomousCouncil (NCHAC), have so far notified 62 services under the RTPS.

title.narrative: Government departments with improved processes for targeted services.

actual.value: As-IS and To-Be studies have been completed for 51 services in 6 departments for Business Process Reengineering (BPR). BPR Studiesfor another 6 services in one existing and one new department (i.e 7 departments) are underway. BPR studies were interrupted by theCOVID situation for three months but have resumed. A project management unit for implementing BPR in the Autonomous Councils isoperational

baseline.value: 30 fully operational Public Facilitation Centers identified.

actual.value: 70 fully operational Public Facilitation Centres identified with 30 centres having 2 mbps internet connectivity. FacilitationManagement vendor for 196 PFCs, covering autonomous council areas and nine other districts, appointed and the centres are beingrefurbished. Letters of Award have been issued for managing another 223 centres.

title.narrative: Number of applications submitted on-line for RTPS services.

actual.value: The RTPS Portal now hosts 25 RTPS services in a live public test version and will be fully launched publicly in November 2020 whilebe scaled up to accommodate more services. Meanwhile, RTPS services not on the portal and some traditionally rendered RTPS servicescontinue to be provided through existing mechanisms.

title.narrative: Number of Services notified under RTPS Act

baseline.value: 55 RTPS services have been notified. under the Act.

target.value: 40 additional RTPS Services over year 4 achievement

actual.value: 80 Government to Citizen RTPS services and 386 Government to Business RTPS Services have been notified so far.

baseline.value: Detailed project report and implementation plan to be approved by GoA.

target.value: Annual Service Delivery Report based on MIS published.

actual.value: The RTPS portal developed by NIC currently hosts 25 services and transactions are taking place. A public launch with 40 onlineservices is expected in November 2020.

title.narrative: Increase in RTPS beneficiary feedback on service delivery

actual.value: The Grievance Redressal system for RTPS services is in the process of development through NIC. A toll-free call centre for RTPS hasbeen established and is functional. The RTPS portal also provides contact details for grievance or feedback. An RTPS IEC campaignwith insights from a comprehensive Communication Needs Assessment study, including citizen feedback and pilot test runs, is readyfor roll-out along with the planned launch of RTPS Portal in November 2020 to help generate demand for services and timely responseby the respective authorities.

title.narrative: Number of applications for RTPS with women as beneficiaries

actual.value: An update to the last measured total of 133,111 RTPS applications with women as beneficiaries as on December 31, 2018 is beingcollected as RTPS is presently rendered through multiple platforms. Meanwhile a box to capture gender of RTPS applicant is afeature in the new RTPS platform developed by NIC. A Customized IEC campaign targeting women has also been carried out. Meanwhileto make the PFCs women friendly roughly 38% of staffing of PFCs is by women.
